body:
### Describe the bug

When cythonizing a simple Python Function with a Type Hinted Optional Argument (see minimal example) the Cythonized Module gives a TypeError upon importing.  

`TypeError: Expected float, got int`

The Optional Typehint breaks the implicit casting between int and float.



### Code to reproduce the behaviour:

```cython
from typing import Optional

# results in an error
def func1(arg: Optional[float]=0):
    pass

# works
def func2(arg: Optional[float]=0.0):
    pass

# works
def func3(arg: float=0):
    pass

```


### Expected behaviour

In my opinion this simple type-cast should be possible as float/int are simply mixed up and these RuntimeErrors are hard to test prior deployment

### OS

Linux

### Python version

3.9.18

### Cython version

3.0.3

### Additional context

_No response_

comment_data.body:
Not quite sure what the best thing to do here.

With `arg: float` the argument is typed as a C float (and so Cython knows the automatic cast from C in to C float).

With `arg: Optional[float]` the argument is typed as a *Python* `float` (or `None`) and so Cython does an exact type-check for the Python object. Right now we don't do much with the knowledge that it's a Python `float`, but in principle any optimizations would be based on that exact type check.

I don't think it's desirable for a default argument and the explicitly passed argument to behave differently.

We could potentially add a coercion in, but I suspect there's a lot of unintended consequences there (for example do we want to silently add a bunch of `tuple` to `list` coercions, because I suspect you'd get those as a side-effect?)

If you ran it through a static type checker like `mypy` (as pure Python code) it'd almost certainly tell you the type annotation is wrong, and I'm inclined to agree. I think this is just a case where we're trying to match Cython's existing, long-established rules against the newer rules for annotation typing in Python in general and they don't quite match up.

> I don't think it's desirable for a default argument and the explicitly passed argument to behave differently.

I'm inclined to agree. I understand that it's surprising to get a runtime error here, also because Python does not give you runtime errors for incorrect type annotations but only build-time type checkers do. It is potentially something that Cython could detect and warn about at compile time, at least in some cases, but probably not all.

> With arg: float the argument is typed as a C float 

This is kind of confusing. It was even surprising for me. I thought that `float` is mapping to `PyObject *`. How types are mapped in pure python mode? In Cython language it is mapping directly to C types:
| Cython      | Result C type |
| ----------- | ----------- |
| `int`      | `int`       |
| `float`   | `float`        |

But in pure python mode it is a mess:

| Pure Python      | Result C type |
| ----------- | ----------- |
| `int`      | `PyObject *`       |
| `cython.int`   | `int`        |
| `float`   | `double`        |
| `cython.float`   | `float`        |

Hence, I think we should come up with clear rule how pure python types are mapped to C types in generated C file. E.g. All python types (int, double, complex, bool, ...) are mapped to `PyObject *` and all `cython.XYZ` are mapped directly to C types. If the type is not recognized by python it should not be allowed only under `cython.TYPE` - e.g. `bar: double` is not allowed but `bar: cython.double` yes

The argument for `int` is that a Python `int` can be arbitrarily big, where as a C `int` can't so they aren't equivalent. In contrast a Python `float` is internally represented by a `double` so we can use that without loss.

The underlying principle is "type hints probably aren't intended for Cython so we should do what's safe".

At one point I proposed an alternative mode where we assume the type hints are for Cython and take them literally (https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4883) since I suspect that's what most people actually mean. But extra modes add complication so aren't always good
I did add a table to the documentation to at least write down all the rules: https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/pure.html#reference-table

> I did add a table to the documentation to at least write down all the rules: https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/pure.html#reference-table

I missed that table. Thanks!

```
def to_str(a: float) -> str:
    return str(a)

num: int = 12345678901234567890
print(to_str(num))
```
This program is accepted by mypy/pyright etc., because [PEP 484 "The numeric tower"](https://peps.python.org/pep-0484/#the-numeric-tower) specifies that type checkers should treat int as a subtype of float (even though at run-time, it isn't).
At run-time, `a` will still be an `int`, and will be printed without any loss of precision: `12345678901234567890`

Compiled with cython, the output changes to `1.2345678901234567e+19`

So strictly speaking, a C `double` is not quite equivalent to a Python `float`, at least not the `: float` used in type annotations.

> ```python
> def to_str(a: float) -> str:
>     return str(a)
> 
> num: int = 12345678901234567890
> print(to_str(num))
> ```

With statically typed code, this is equivalent to:

```python
Python 3.10.12 (main, Jun 11 2023, 05:26:28) [GCC 11.4.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> def to_str(a: float) -> str:
...     return str(float(a))
... 
>>> num: int = 12345678901234567890
>>> print(to_str(num))
1.2345678901234567e+19
```
Thus, I get the same result in Python.

I completely understand what you are saying. However, if you explicitly type your function argument as Python `float`, then you are asking for the code to process the values as Python `float`. If you do not want your code to use Python `float` values, then do not ask for it.

> With `arg: float` the argument is typed as a C float

We should better say "C double" here. It's equivalent to a Python `float`, just unboxed.

I think we got distracted in the whole discussion. Let's get back to the actual problem of `a: float` behaving differently from `a: Optional[float]` for numeric input values.

I could imagine adding a type conversion in addition to the type check. Basically, anything that has a `__float__` method (respectively [`nb_float`](https://docs.python.org/3/c-api/typeobj.html#c.PyNumberMethods.nb_float) in C) seems appropriate as input. We could do the type check (exact type and `None`, if allowed), and if that fails, apply the conversion to make sure that we either have an exact `float` or raise the expected `TypeError`.

I'll target this issue to Cython 3.1 since it's probably too late to change this in Cython 3.0.

[copied from https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/6808#issuecomment-2833273190]
> I wonder if a better short-term fix would be to special-case the type of `Optional[float]` (and maybe `Optional[complex]`?) as `object` and ignore the `float` part.

On the contrary, maybe if it's worth always accepting subtypes (and other compatible numbers) for `int`, `float`, `complex` declarations, and just converting them to the plain builtin type. Even if that's not well in line with Python typing semantics either, it's probably still better than strictly rejecting them, as we do now.


> Just on the basis that we don't really do any optimizations for Python `float` anyway since we assume it'll usually be replaced by C `float`.

I don't think that's true. If we mix object and C double, we end up with object as computation type. If we mix Python float and C double, I think we already infer the result type as C double.

milestone.description: First feature release after the cleanup releases 3.0 and 3.1.

title: [BUG] Optional Typehint breaks implicit int to float conversion
